newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela businesses question social security plan.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela businesses question social security plan.

text.p: Proposed changes in Venezuela's social security system got a lukewarm reception from business leaders on Friday when union leaders formally presented their reform plans to the tripartite commission.

The commission gathers private sector leaders, union and government officials in an attempt to break a long-standing impasse over social security reform -- seen as a prerequisite for a long awaited restructuring of the 1.2 million strong Venezuelan public sector.
"There are some matters in their proposal that worry us," leading business chamber Fedecamaras president Jorge Serrano told reporters.

Under current rules, fired workers are paid twice their monthly salary for each year worked while retiring workers are paid once. Government and private sector leaders say such a scheme prevents increases in worker salaries. Take home pay is boosted instead, when needed, with monthly bonds.
Under changes proposed by Venezuela's largest union, the Confederation of Venezuelan Workers (CTV), workers would be paid severance payments according to a sliding scale.
Workers on salaries less than 53,000 bolivars a month would receive three months salary for each year worked, while those with salaries over 500,000 bolivars would receive one month's pay.
CTV president Federico Ramirez Leon said the scale favored those who are paid less "which are most is this country".
But Serrano said he favored moving towards a new system of social security payments rather than a tinkering of the current method.
